content:
I was proud to join the House Natural Resources Committee hearing on Environmental Justice for Coal Country yesterday. We need to understand that rural and tribal coal communities are on the front lines of energy transition and current rules and regulations at the Interior Dept are not providing proper oversight to manage the transition away from a coal economy in many of these communities.

In many cases, these communities are doubly impacted, not just by the environmental impacts of the mining, but also by mining companies’ failure to pay for remediation as the mines close. If we do not strengthen our safeguards, bankrupt coal companies will continue to shed healthcare, pension, and environmental cleanup responsibilities, causing further damage to the communities affected by the coal industry’s decline.

https://www.wvgazettemail.com/news/energy_and_environment/house-hearing-highlights-concerns-with-federal-mine-reclamation-oversight-as-state-leaders-look-to-feds/article_13268884-df3b-543e-9846-694d7f6cbc63.html

WVGAZETTEMAIL.COM
House hearing highlights concerns with federal mine reclamation oversight as state leaders look to feds for reclamation help
name: Alan S. Lowenthal
text: proud join house natural resources committee hearing environmental justice coal country yesterday need understand rural tribal coal communities front lines energy transition current rules regulations interior dept providing proper oversight manage transition away coal economy many communitiesin many cases communities doubly impacted environmental impacts mining also mining companies failure pay remediation mines close strengthen safeguards bankrupt coal companies continue shed healthcare pension environmental cleanup responsibilities causing damage communities affected coal industrys declinewvgazettemailcomhouse hearing highlights concerns federal mine reclamation oversight state leaders look feds reclamation help
